Description: Egyptian terracotta figure of Harpocrates wearing a headdress (two lotus buds) with hair in side knot. Head only. Mould-made and hollow. White (gypsum?) coating. Red-brown Nile silt fabric. Abundant fine gold mica, quartz, organics and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Probably made in Naukratis. Gutch dated this piece to between 150BC and 250AD (Gutch in Hogarth 1899, pl. 12, no. 219). A similar, but unprovenanced, parallel from Dresden was dated to the late Hellenistic period (Fischer 1994, pl. 56. no. 562) and another was given a Roman date (Dunand 1990, no. 287). Dunand, F. 1990, Musée du Louvre. Département des antiquités égyptiennes. Catalogue des terres cuites grécoromaines d'Egypte, Paris. Fischer, J. 1994. Griechisch-römische Terrakotten aus Ägypten. Die Sammlungen Sieglin und Schreiber. Dresden, Leipzig, Stuttgart, Tübingen. Tübingen, Wasmuth.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.064) (Phase 1)
Gutch 1898/1899 / Excavations at Naukratis, D. The Terracottas (p. 94, no. 219, pl. XII, no. 219)
